fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Guarded cubical type theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @article{bbcgsv-2019, author = {Birkedal, Lars and Bizjak, Ale\v{s} and Clouston, Ranald and Grathwohl, Hans Bugge and Spitters, Bas and Vezzosi, Andrea}, year = {2019}, doi = {10.1007/s10817-018-9471-7}, journal = {Journal of Automated Reasoning}, number = {2}, pages = {211--253}, title = {Guarded Cubical Type Theory}, volume = {63}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This paper improves the treatment of equality in guarded dependent type theory (ùñ¶ùñ£ùñ≥ùñ≥), by combining it with cubical type theory (ùñ¢ùñ≥ùñ≥). ùñ¶ùñ£ùñ≥ùñ≥ is an extensional type theory with guarded recursive types, which are useful for building models of program logics, and for programming and reasoning with coinductive types. We wish to implement ùñ¶ùñ£ùñ≥ùñ≥ with decidable type checking, while still supporting non-trivial equality proofs that reason about the extensions of guarded recursive constructions. ùñ¢ùñ≥ùñ≥ is a variation of Martin-L√∂f type theory in which the identity type is replaced by abstract paths between terms. ùñ¢ùñ≥ùñ≥ provides a computational interpretation of functional extensionality, enjoys canonicity for the natural numbers type, and is conjectured to support decidable type-checking. Our new type theory, guarded cubical type theory (ùñ¶ùñ¢ùñ≥ùñ≥), provides a computational interpretation of extensionality for guarded recursive types. This further expands the foundations of ùñ¢ùñ≥ùñ≥ as a basis for formalisation in mathematics and computer science. We present examples to demonstrate the expressivity of our type theory, all of which have been checked using a prototype type-checker implementation. We show that ùñ¢ùñ≥ùñ≥ can be given semantics in presheaves on \mathcal {C}\times \mathbb {D}, where \mathcal {C} is the cube category, and \mathbb {D} is any small category with an initial object. We then show that the category of presheaves on \mathcal {C}\times \omega provides semantics for ùñ¶ùñ¢ùñ≥ùñ≥.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Most practical programming languages have side effects: state, input-output, errors, etc.
Monads capture the structure of side effects (Moggi, Wadler).
State means being able to interact with the computer‚Äôs memory; references or pointers govern access to a location in memory.
The syntax of state varies along three axes:

html:p.html:em: What kind of things can be stored in memory cells?
When can these memory cells be allocated?
What equations hold of stateful computations?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Storing only integers or other first-order data.

Models of very extensional equational theory including ‚Äúgarbage collection‚Äù found by Plotkin, Power; Staton. Adapted to ‚Äúfull ground store‚Äù (storage of pointers) by Kammar, Levy, Moss, and Staton.
Extensionality of models lost when moving to higher-order storage.
An extreme point in the design space...
Deeply impredicative: heap contains elements of arbitrary types.
\Longrightarrow guarded recursion (step-indexing) used to break the circularity.
An equational theory of higher-order store in which reads to the heap leave behind ‚Äúbreadcrumbs‚Äù.
Consider two implementations of an ‚Äúcounter‚Äù object:

html:p.html:em: What is the relationship between \mathsf {posCounter} and \mathsf {negCounter}?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: They appear to be indistinguishable. Indeed, they are ‚Äúobservationally equivalent‚Äù!

Observational equivalence is an extremely weak property: indistinguishability under observations of ground type only. It would be great if we could instead deduce an absolute equation: \color {red}\vdash \mathsf {posCounter} \equiv \mathsf {negCounter} \colon \mathsf {Counter} (No cheating: we want ‚Äústandard‚Äù models without extensional collapse or logical relation.)
We add two additional rules to the equational theory of guarded higher-order dynamic allocation.

CELL UNIVALENCE. For f^+\colon A\to B and f^-\colon B\to A with x:B\vdash f^+{\mathopen {}\left (f^-{\mathopen {}\left (x\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}\equiv x and x\colon A\vdash f^-{\mathopen {}\left (f^+{\mathopen {}\left (x\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} \equiv x we have:
The theory of univalent reference types derives \vdash \mathsf {posCounter} \equiv \mathsf {negCounter}.
The function \mathsf {neg} \colon \mathsf {Integer}\to \mathsf {Integer} is inverse to itself; therefore, apply CELL UNIVALENCE with f^+ \equiv f^- \equiv \mathsf {neg} and simplify.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: S., Gratzer, and Birkedal (2022) found synthetic denotational semantics for guarded higher-order dynamic allocation in an impredicative version of guarded dependent type theory (iGDTT).
Guarded recursion needed to solve the domain equation; impredicativity needed to define the monad (b/c \mathsf {Heap} is large).

Our main observation is that a slight variation on SGB‚Äô22 suffices to model univalent reference types, so long as both \mathbf {FinSet} and \mathbf {Set} are both univalent universes in the sense of Voevodsky.

html:ol.html:li: Univalence of \mathbf {FinSet} implies the LAYOUT UNIVALENCE rule.
Univalence of \mathbf {Set} implies the CELL UNIVALENCE rule.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We therefore need an impredicative version of guarded homotopy type theory.
We define iGHoTT to be the extension of Martin-L√∂f‚Äôs intensional type theory by the following additional features:

html:ol.html:li: homotopy type theory: the univalence axiom
guarded recursion: later modality \mathord {\blacktriangleright } and solutions to guarded fixed points
a univalent impredicative universe, i.e. a universe \mathcal {S}\in \mathcal {U} closed under families of \mathcal {S}-small types indexed in a \mathcal {U}-small type.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In iGHoTT, we can define a model of univalent reference types. The real question is whether we can find a model of iGHoTT.
Palombi and S. (2023) have contributed a modular method for building models of (non-univalent) guarded dependent type theory over an arbitrary base topos. As applied by SGB‚Äô22:

html:ol.html:li: Any realisability topos \mathcal {E} contains an impredicative universe \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {E}}.

Then the relative presheaf topos \mathcal {F} :\equiv {\mathopen {}\left [\mathbb {O}^{\mathsf {op}},\mathcal {E}\right ]\mathclose {}} is a model of guarded recursion and contains an impredicative universe \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {F}} defined from \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {E}} by Hofmann‚ÄîStreicher lifting.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We have not gotten around to adapting the SGB‚Äô22 model of iGDTT to obtain a model of iGHoTT, which is much more complicated.

html:ol.html:li: Let \mathbb {A} be a partial combinatory algebra.
Let \square be a suitable internal cube category in \mathbf {PER}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}, and let \mathbb {O} be an internal well-founded order in the same.

Then the category of internal presheaves of assemblies {\mathopen {}\left [{\mathopen {}\left (\square \times \mathbb {O}\right )\mathclose {}}^{\mathsf {op}},\mathbf {Asm}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}\right ]\mathclose {}} is expected to form a model of iGHoTT{}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Impredicative HoTT via cubical assemblies due to Awodey et al. and studied by Uemura, Swan.
Guarded HoTT via \square \times \mathbb {O} due to Birkedal et al. (2019).

fr:title.text: A more canonical model of iGHoTT?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A more canonical model of iGHoTT?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Even if internal presheaves of assemblies on \square \times \mathbb {O} works, the resulting model will be uncanonical from the {\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-categorical standpoint.
For example, if \mathbb {O}=\omega , we shall not have defined the ‚Äúinternal (pre)-{\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-topos of trees‚Äù in cubical assemblies.

More canonical approach would be to take internal presheaves on any \mathcal {S}-small well-founded order \mathbb {O} internal to the {\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-category \mathcal {E} presented by {\mathopen {}\left [\square ^{\mathsf {op}},\mathbf {Asm}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}\right ]\mathclose {}}. This may introduce coherence problems that we are currently unprepared for.

fr:title.text: Comparing with other realisability models of state

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Comparing with other realisability models of state

fr:mainmatter.html:p: SGB‚Äô22 were not the first to combine guarded recursion with realisability to model higher-order dynamic allocation; see Birkedal, St√∏vring, and Thamsborg (2010).

However, op.cit. relied on a specific realisability model based on an untyped domain model of a stateful language; in contrast, the model construction of SGB‚Äô22 applies uniformly for any pair {\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {E},\mathbb {O}\right )\mathclose {}}.
Thus SGB‚Äô22 showed that realisability is inessential: if we find any other viable source of impredicative universes besides realisability, SGB‚Äô22 would apply there too.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We develop a denotational semantics for general reference types in an impredicative version of guarded homotopy type theory, an adaptation of synthetic guarded domain theory to Voevodsky‚Äôs univalent foundations. We observe for the first time the profound impact of univalence on the denotational semantics of mutable state. Univalence automatically ensures that all computations are invariant under symmetries of the heap‚Äîa bountiful source of program equivalences. In particular, even the most simplistic univalent model enjoys many new program equivalences that do not hold when the same constructions are carried out in the universes of traditional set-level (extensional) type theory.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Weeknotes 2025-W15 ‚Ä∫ Two papers to appear in LICS ‚Äô25 ‚Ä∫ With Andrew Slattery: Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting of fibred categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This year, Thomas Streicher (born 1958) passed away from cancer. Thomas was one of the Greats of dependent type theory and he also wrote an excellent textbook on domain theory for denotational semantics, but much more importantly he was kind and curious and patient and always made time for young people. While I was still finding my place in the community, Thomas was very generous to me with his time and advice, and he sent me many papers to referee.

Although Thomas made many contributions to dependent type theory, domain theory, realisability theory, and category theory, he is most known to type theorists for two things‚Äîboth in collaboration with the late Martin Hofmann: the groupoid interpretation of type theory and the eponymous Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher universe lifting construction. Andrew and my paper pertains to the latter.

The idea of Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting has to do with universes, which are ‚Äútypes of types‚Äù (typically defined in such a way as to avoid paradoxes). Martin-L√∂f type theory usually includes universes in order to be able to quantify over (small enough) types; in the simplest models of Martin-L√∂f type theory, types are interpreted as sets and so Martin-L√∂f‚Äôs universes are interpreted as certain sets of sets, such as Grothendieck universes. But it is important to be able to interpret the language of type theory in more sophisticated worlds than set theory: for example, in presheaves (which are functors from a fixed category C into Set). What Hofmann and Streicher did is show how to transform any universe of sets into a universe of presheaves!

Although Hofmann and Streicher‚Äôs construction worked well and had good properties, they did not find a universal property for it‚Äîwhich is an abstract description of the object that determines it uniquely up to isomorphism, usually in terms of how it relates to other objects. Recently Awodey found a 1-dimensional universal property, which was the starting point of our work. What Andrew and I wanted to do is generalise Awodey‚Äôs analysis in two directions:

html:ol.html:li: We wanted a 2-dimensional version, which is useful because it captures more about the universe than can be said in just one dimension: for example, with a 2-dimensional version, you can see immediately (by ‚Äúabstract nonsense‚Äù) that Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting preserves structures like monads, adjunctions, etc. that might be used for modelling computational effects, etc.

We wanted a relative version, which would make it easier to iterate the Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting construction: the purpose of this is to be able to define presheaf models of type theory internal to other presheaf models. These kind of situations actually happen in practice! For example, the model of guarded cubical type theory that combines step-indexing with univalence ought to be an example of this.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: To develop this two-fold generalisation of Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting, we resituated the theory in terms of another of Thomas‚Äôs favourite topics: the theory of fibrations, on which Thomas had written the most wonderful lecture notes.
We dedicated our paper to Thomas‚Äôs memory. May he rest in peace.
